column11: Review Text

A great 40 minute visit. Kaveesh guided us round and talked through the different stages of turtle life, as we saw very young through old turtles in about 8 tanks. We had never seen turtles like this before, or even thought about the dangers of ocean plastics, nets and boats to the animals. Both educational and fun; thoroughly recommend.

We had a wonderful visit. The staff greeted us warmly, and the entry fee was very reasonable. They took us on a guided walk around the center, explaining the life cycle of the turtles and the different species they protect. We got to see their most recent hatchery with expected hatching dates, and then each tank where they carefully described the turtles inside and the treatments or rehabilitation they were receiving. The team is incredibly knowledgeable, friendly, and you can genuinely feel how much they care about their work. The whole area is clean, peaceful, and not overly touristy, which makes the experience feel more authentic and dedicated to real conservation. Overall, it‚Äôs informative, meaningful, and absolutely worth the visit. Highly recommend!

column8: Kind people, beautiful turtles, incredible beach
column11: Great turtle rescue center. The cost is 2,000 Lankan rupees per person. A very nice guy talks about the turtles they save and shows all the stages. We couldn't get the turtle out. Nearby very beautiful beach The center has very nice and kind people )

column8: üåøA Truly Inspiring Experience at the Turtle Center. üê¢
column11: Visiting this turtle conservation center was one of the most moving experiences we‚Äôve ever had. From the moment we arrived, we could feel the care, dedication, and love that the staff and volunteers pour into protecting these incredible creatures. Seeing the rescued turtles up close ‚Äî some recovering from injuries, others preparing to be released back into the ocean ‚Äî was both humbling and hopeful. The team took the time to explain each stage of the conservation process, from hatching to rehabilitation, and their passion was contagious. What touched us most was how personal it all felt. Every turtle has a story, and the staff share those stories with such tenderness that you can‚Äôt help but fall in love with these gentle beings. Having the honor to watch one of their turtles make its way toward and back into the ocean we‚Äôll never forget ‚Äî a reminder of the power of kindness and the importance of protecting our planet. This place doesn‚Äôt just rescue turtles; it restores hope. üê¢üíö If you ever have the chance to visit or support their work, don‚Äôt hesitate ‚Äî you‚Äôll leave with a full heart and a renewed respect for the ocean and all its life. Thank you Charith. Thank you for the work you do and thank you for the fresh coconut üå¥ ü••. You were the highlight of our mother/daughter Sri Lanka trip. üíôüíö

Very beautiful place, with loads of different sea turtles across all five of the species native to Sri Lanka! The staff were very friendly and toured me round, allowing me to learn about the conservation. The beach location is also great.

column8: A Wonderful and Educational Experience with Turtles
column11: We visited this turtle hatchery hoping for a meaningful and educational experience for our children, and it exceeded our expectations. Our guide was incredibly informative and engaging, helping the kids understand the dangers turtles face in Sri Lanka and explaining the species that are common in the region. A real highlight was being able to hold some baby green turtles‚Äîa truly beautiful experience, especially as it was the children‚Äôs first time interacting with them. We also got to see how the team rescues and cares for injured or disabled turtles, which was both fascinating and eye-opening. It was not only educational but also inspiring to see the dedication of the staff. Our guide mentioned that the funds generated from visits go directly towards feeding and caring for the turtles, which made the experience feel even more meaningful. We would definitely recommend this visit to anyone, especially families looking for an educational and hands-on experience with wildlife.

column8: Well worth the visit - Turtle sanctuary
column11: Well worth a stop on the way to and from Colombo. Interesting and educational on the life cycle and plight of these incredible creatures. I really does emphasize the need to look after our environment when you hear of the impact of waste in the water on their lives and habitat
This place seems like a good place where they treat the turtles well. Very informative guide who was good at telling and answering our questions. Great recommendation from here.

column8: Visit to the Galbokka Sea Turtle Conservation and Research Center
column11: Kaveesha was a wonderful guide. He explained the aims of the conservation project. His enthusiasm and dedication were obvious. We were lucky to see turtles hatching and also observe some that have been rescued and cared for.

We arrived with no booking but that was no issue, the staff were super friendly and knowledgeable about the turtles. It‚Äôs clear they care about them. The centre is small and less touristy than others which we liked and it‚Äôs placed on a beautiful beach. We paid extra to release baby turtles into the sea which was a bucket list moment. The staff helped taking our pics and videos whilst we watched the turtles go off into the sea with the sun setting. Highly recommend we had a brilliant time.

Amazing trip we loved it ! Watching the turtles swim to the ocean was so beautiful.  This place is as ethical as they can be its a tough life for a turtle in the wild, thank you for such a wonderful experience

This turtle centre is amazing to learn more about this animal. They are very respectful of the species and environemt, teach a lot of things and are very nice. You can see baby turtles, old ones, rescued (in a healing process). I recommend visiting there !

Such an amazing experience! We were slightly anxious ahead of visiting that this would be a tourist trap but couldn't have been further from the truth.  We had the most amazing tour to ourselves then the opportunity to release some 1 day old turtles.  Unlike reviews from other nearby hatcheries, Galbokka are not holding onto any turtles unnecessarily for tourists and it was definitely value for money - spending almost 2 hours there! Such an amazing team, including their gorgeous dog!

An organization that really cares for injured sea turtles. And when the sea turtles are healthy again they are let back into the sea. Little ones are also born here and then released into the sea. These people are very friendly and the animals are central!

O.M.G what a amazing place to visit a very informative guide telling you all to need to know about turtles and there welfare,these volunteers are so passionate about the survival of these lovely creatures,we even released some turtles back into the sea which was amazing,you can sponsor some turtle eggs 100 rupees per egg,for that they will send you WhatsApp of them hatching,all the money goes back into saving these fantastic creatures,you are not pressured to do this or donate any money it‚Äôs 2000 rupees entrance fee and another 1000 rupee if you want to release some,worth every rupee as well as knowing the money will help this establishment keep up the good work!

This was an amazing turtle hatchery. They were very passionate and knowledgeable. Truly a conservation treasure. They had hatchlings born yesterday (14/03/2024). They will be releasing them very soon. They had a. Couple which have been injured and have buoyancy issues and can never be released into the sea again‚Ä¶. Sad as they have been injured by fishing boats.

A hidden treasure off the beaten track. We found this place purely by accident (with the help of a friendly local) and had a wonderful hour or so being given a wonderful tour of the nursery. The staff were friendly and passionate about their cause and cannot recommend this small conservation centre enough.

It is really worth every second, they do their best to clarify your doubts and explain each of the cases. Turtles that are in rehabilitation with them, their characteristics and ways of life and the best, being able to go at sunset and participate in the release of the turtles, is a unique and wonderful moment that we will always carry in our hearts. Thank you for the work you do, for the love you give to turtles and for teaching them. More about them! We are going to Chile happier thanks to you.

We went for a short walk from our hotel  (Riu) and came across this place. It was small, quiet and welcoming. We had a little private tour with a young guide, that was very friendly and spoke perfect English. We really enjoyed his company and were amazed how dedicated to turtles conservation were are the staff members. We were allowed to hold 2 small turtles and stroke the bigger ones. It was a nice experience for us but I'm not sure if it's good for the animals. Overall I recommend visit to this place and supporting their work with a donation.

This a small hatchery / sea turtle centre that is definitely going to make a difference to the turtle population of Sri Lanka. The tour was very informative, knowledgeable and genuine. You can sense the passion the hatchery has for the turtles and their environment. The majority of the hatched turtles are returned to sea after hatching a few kept until they are juveniles to try and increase their chances of survival. The cost of visiting the centre is very reasonable but there is also a donation box that you can donate a little extra that will allow the purchase of turtle nest eggs to relocate to the hatchery to give them a better chance of survival. We adopted a nest which we will be receiving photos and videos via WhatsApp on their hatching which is a great bonus. I hope this hatchery gets the support it deserves to continue with their great work they are doing.

Amazing place and wonderful experience. Not to be missed! It‚Äôs a small place and the tour was very personalised, informative and moving. The dedication of the team and volunteers to help the turtles and the ocean really shines through.

Charith and Manjula give a very interesting presentation about the life cycle of turtles, and all the problems mostly caused by humans. You can see damaged turtles that they try where possible to heal. They have only a few very small turtles because keeping the turtles, more than some days is not good. So the young turtles are released as soon as possible at the beach at the right time to make sure they enter the ocean safely. This is not Europe, so the protection program is fully based on donations by visitors. You can donate the costs of eggs, if available, and make the experience of putting the eggs yourself in the clean and protected sand with the Hatchery.  The act are usually brought by people from the village to the Hatchery. They get money for the eggs, otherwise they would eat them or sell them. That was very normal not so long ago and the people in this country are to a large extent poor and very poor. Charith is also willing to give a very interesting tour in the Temple close by.  he knows a lot about Buddhism and he practices its principles. Don‚Äôt forget to donate if you visit them. They will not ask for money, but there is a box at the entrance where you may put in money. With $12 can save a whole nest of turtles. When the turtles hatch, they sent you a video if you leave your WhatsApp number.  For me, it was a great experience and I have been there several times last year and I will this year. Make sure you go to this one and not strand in another one. Is it not so easy to find, is nearly at the end of the beach,  if you come over the beach walking to Galbokka.  The walk at the beach is wonderful.  If you come by Tuktuk be aware that some drivers prefer  to bring you to another hatchery,  because they get money or because it belongs to family or friends.  Make sure clear where you want to go. Enjoy

Staff were very friendly and knowledgeable about turtles learnt some interesting facts Good price cost 2000lkr each There's lots of turtles here, different ages and one's that are being rehabilitated before being released I think they do turtle releasing into the wild during hatching season as well Turtle feeding is in the morning and evening The beach it goes onto is worth a look as it is stunning

What a great experience we had at the Galbokka Sea Turtle Hatchery. Charit was so knowledgeable and explained everything to us so well. It was really a lovely experience and the best part was that we got to hold the baby sea turtles which i believe is not allowed at all hatcheries!  Sea turtles take two months to hatch and we were lucky enough to see quite a few babies that had just hatched. Unfortunately we left the same afternoon and missed letting the babies out into the sea which was to happen that evening. We went specifically to this hatchery after reading the reviews and they certainly lived up to it. This place is not at all commercialized which is great too. All in all, a must visit when in Bentota.

There are many turtle hatcheries along the South West coast of Sri Lanka, and not all of them have the best intentions. I found Galbokka again via Tripadvisor and our experience couldn't have been much better. We saw several species of turtles that were stuck there (injured animals that cannot be returned to the wild), as well as a hatchery of eggs rescued from the beach, as well as baby turtles that were a few days old. We received an extensive explanation from the caretakers, who also knew a lot about the animals. The price was Rs 1000/person, our daughter (5yrs) got in for free, and there was never any insistence on an extra tip, even though they operate entirely on donations. Because of the good experience, I made a large donation, more than deserved!

If you ever have the opportunity, please visit the little turtel farm, which is a lovely place to bee. The owner is very friendly and you will get the opportunity to let the small turtels in the see, if you come at the right time in the evening ours.

We chose to stop at a center, Galbokka Sea Turtle Conservation & Research Center, about an hour north of Hikkaduwa, on our way to Colombo. The place has several small ponds that are used to rehabilitate injured sea turtles, to raise and strengthen newly born sea turtles, and a complex of nests that were copied from the beach to keep the eggs. When we were there, we saw 3 types of sea turtles and tiny turtles that were just born that morning that are kept in a tank until the evening when it gets dark to increase their chances of survival. For sea turtle lovers, it seems and feels that they care, they doing a great effort to help theses sea turtles and their goal is to restore the sea turtle population, but they don't have the financial ability to do everything they would like, the ponds are small, the turtles are big, and there are also For example, a case of an injured sea turtle that got air in its shell so that it can't dive and lives in a really small water tank, which was very difficult to see, on the other hand, they don't have the money to finance the treatment that this turtle needs to return it to the sea. The entrance costs 2000 Sri Lankan rupees, which is their source of income to finance the place. According to what we were told, they do not have any government funding. The money they get used to buy sea turtle eggs that are collected by fishermen to sell for food, buy food for some of the turtles, a veterinarian when needed, maintenance, and more, all financed by the place only. One of the workers gave us a tour and explained everything they do at the center, and answered all of our questions. In this center, only 3 people work in total. They would be happy for volunteers, including volunteer families, to help with all the center's current activities, including releasing turtles into the sea. From what I understand, you can just reach them, they hardly have any volunteers, and you can also contact them on their Facebook page. If we didn't have a flight the next day, we would have stayed there for a few days. The relevant period is between November to April.

I was hesitant in deciding on which turtle hatchery to visit in the area as I wanted to ensure I was visiting a site that legitimately cared for the welfare of the sea turtles.  This hatchery was recommended to me by a local and it was evident from the moment we arrived that the well-being of the turtles is of paramount importance at this site.  The guide was very knowledgeable on sea turtles and was able to answer all our questions.  The price to visit (and pay extra for a turtle release if you choose to) is incredibly cheap considering the price the hatchery pays to help and care for the turtles.

These people are doing such amazing work. Was a real eye opener to see the damage we humans are causing to these beautiful creatures, We had an extremely knowledgeable guide who was able to answer all our questions. Got to briefly hold both baby turtles & adults & see where they incubate eggs to enable the release of baby turtles back into the ocean. Left having gained a real insight into the struggle these animals face
Seems like an amazing place! These people are doing a great thing helping the turtles highly recommended!

An incredibly great experience! The Turtle Center is run with a lot of passion. The animals always have first priority. They work with simple means and always take care of the environment through recycling. A big compliment and a big thank you to the staff!
Good to visit if you want to learn more about sea life. Very nice staff! Really fantastic visit. Could to see lot of turtles!

A good place. People explain the life of turtles well. They have imagers and they also give a sound news of how to protect themselves ( the animal ). We spend a lots of time and we also see one animal was dye in the sea on the same day. That was sad.

This is an amazing place with an amazing mission. Plenty of cute little and big turtles of different types to see here. You can experience the hatching of baby turtles, to petting the biggest of them. Highly recommending checking this place, it is run by great hardworking and dedicated volunteers! :)

What to say!!!! We went on galbokka sea turtle hatchery on the last of our 4day trip in sri lanka, on the way of the airport... it is the highlight of our journey! The most beautiful and unforgettable experience we had! Kids were as amazed as we do! There we have been welcomed by Dilshan and had a tour by him. We really feel that he is devoted and love his job and the sea turtles. As much as he could transmit a part of his feeling. He raised our awareness regarding how the man impact the life of these turtles and especially over fishing and plastic. The tour was extremely educative! Dilshan was able to answer aaaaallll our questions. He even illustrates his explanations by real pictures or videos he took before (rescued turtles catch in a fishing net, surgery, laying turtle) At the end we did a donation for a nest, and released baby turtles at sunset time. Again Unforgettable experience. We are waiting to hear from the green turtle nest we ¬´¬†adopt¬†¬ª and can not wait them to be released into the sea. Please visit this place. To help them, either with donation or by learning more and be aware of how to protect sea turtles and marine life in general. üôèüèªüôèüèªüôèüèª Thank you again

Very interesting experience! Those guys are really making the difference into the conservation of sea turtle. Lots of explanations and get to see some turtles as well. A good way for them to work with tourist to be able to collect some money and continue fighting for this beautiful cause as they don‚Äôt receive any help from The government.

Visited the Galbokka Turtle Center and got a good and very informative tour. The guide told me everything about all the different sea turtles and the hatchery. They really care about the turtles. For me it was sometimes difficult to see that injured turtles can hardly be released sometime. But they are taking very good care! It is for sure worthwhile visiting.

Super fun, interactive and educational experience for all ages. I've learnt alot about conservation and all things related from the very knowledgeable crew here at Lang Tengah. The whole set up is very well set up to be eco friendly, with clear policies which put nature and the turtles first. The research projects are meaningful and extremely.

Always love to visit turtle rehabilitation centers. The turtles need all the help they can get and these folks are doing their best. Love to be able to support places like this that do such admirable work.

Informative visit to see the great work being done by this team to help with turtle conservation. The guide was very knowledgeable and the turtles being held at the conservatory for various reasons eg due to disabilities or injuries seemed to be well taken care of. This is a great place to see different types of turtles and learn about how to make a difference.

Four of us went, the staff were very rude,to the point they pointed out that one person was medium build and two were fat. All they seemed interested in was money, no information was given about the turtles. 3000 rupees each plus 500 rupees entrance. Staff member dug up turtle and said that they were alive but looked dead. We were allowed three turtles each for release. Would not recommend this place, very disappointed.

Great engaged team doing incredible work from conservation project to education. I was not really interested in the topic but so happy we stopped by and got to learn more about the turtles, the project and meet these incredible people

We had the privilege to visit this amazing conservation centre yesterday it was a place I‚Äôd read reviews on before I left the UK based on them I‚Äôd planned to visit the Hatchery and was not disappointed in fact I‚Äôm not sure that any of the reviews give them the justice they deserve for the work they do. They rescue and return injured turtles to the sea and where that isn‚Äôt possible they are cared for at the centre. Money donations are used for the welfare of turtles money being used to buy eggs from the ,local fisherman in order to hatch them returning the baby turtles to the sea. We had a magical moment where the staff allowed us to return some babies and to watch the walk through the sand to the sea was memorable. The staff are very knowledgeable and clearly very passionate about what they do and will happily talk to you about the work they do. We discovered that the BBC filmed here and had highly commended the work being carried out. Sadly we leave Sri Lanka in a few days otherwise we would have made a return visit it‚Äôs a true experience
The guys there are doing amazing job saving sea turtles and are eagerly sharing their knowledge. We got the chance to release small turtles into the ocean. Experience that leaves best memories :).

I am always a bit sceptical about some of these so called conservation projects that happen to be located in tourist locations, but having visited Kosgoda Sea Turtle Conservation Project today, I am certainly happy to recommend it. We spoke at length to the staff and volunteers who help run it and they are very knowledgable about the turtle species, their history and their probability of survival. They are earnest in their determination to make a difference in both helping the turtles survive, but also educating others in actions that we all need to take. Yes they allow visitors to participate by burying the eggs, but they made sure there was no sweat on our hands to contaminate them first. We never felt under pressure to buy merchandise or other money making schemes, although we did manage to buy some t shirts, but this was because we wanted to make a donation to their work and take away a momento as well as some pictures and wonderful memories. The large turtles that are kept in the tanks were there because they had been rescued following injuries mainly caused by human negligence. Fishing nets appear to be one of the most frequent causes. After a period of recuperation and care, they will be returned to the sea. A couple will never be returned to the sea because their injuries will almost certainly mean they will not survive. My overall impression was that if you are prepared to show interest in the work being carried out here, then the people who run are more than happy to spend as much time as you want telling you about the work that they carry out here.
Really nice place where they take very good care of the turtles. Very nice and helpful staff! I can really recommend it.

You have to go here. The staff are so knowledgeable and passionate about the turtles. They don't keep any animals just for entertainment purposes, every turtle that can be released is let into the wild. It's 1000lkr per person for entry and to release the baby hatchlings into the sea, which is great value too.

Doubles as a hatchery and wounded turtle rescue centre, rehabilitating turtles that have lost limbs in fishing nets. Often 18-24 months to make them well enough to get back to sea.  The hatchery was great and we got to release a couple of babies back to the big bad world. Very nice people to take you around and explain all, nice experience

I visited here at the beginning of the December by chance as I wanted to find a sea turtle organization near the Riu. The ticket was very reasonable at 500 lkr for a tour but I would have happily given more. The guys working here are so passionate and care so much about what they do! It was lovely to hear that the current owner had it passed down from his dad and still restarted after the natural disaster. They were knowledgeable about all the species and explained why each turtle was there (although many were very sad stories of finding the turtles injured). I would highly recommend visiting and donating. It was a real highlight for me being a lover of turtles, I ended up spending 2 hours here.

The young man who was both knowledgable, passionate and dedicated about sea turtles explained the work of the hatchery. They take great care of the turtles injured through fishing nets, and once treated release them back into the sea. They also take care of the eggs (prevent being eaten by birds etc) until they hatch. Thank you for such an informative visit.

We were taken round the hatchery by a young man who was full of information on the turtles and the work done in the hatchery, and clearly very passionate about his work. We saw the hatching beds, then a batch of newly hatched turtles ready for release that evening. They also have some rescued adult turtles, mainly injured in some way, which appear to be well cared for. It was fascinating, and seems to be a very worthwhile cause. My only qualm was being able to hold the turtles, even the newly hatched ones. A tourist's dream, to be sure, but is it really the best thing for the turtles?

Absolutely adored this visit..the staff are passionate about Turtle Conservation and house a few with deformities which are so well looked after and used for breeding Also love the rare albino  one called Micheal Jackson who has to be kept under lock and key at night to prevent him being stolen and made into some useless ornament!!! The staff are so kind and I found the visit very informative and applaud what they are doing There were lots of babies due to be released so in my mind I named the one I held and wished her well.......maybe this could be a way of generating more money..pay to name a baby turtle I would have paid to do so!!! I would also have paid to watch their release but would have got too upset if any didn't make it!! Many thanks and well done to the wonderful staff for all your are doing for conservation
This was very interesting and great to see the important work that they do, not only hatching the eggs and realising the baby turtles but also the way they look after the injured adults.

Simply Brilliant Turtles are lovely. And they do a really good job. Note that if you want to see them release the turtles to the sea, they do this every evening, so call in advance. There is also a charge to *Watch* and participate in the release of the turtles. This is how they get money to buy the eggs so that the turtles are able to survive in the first place. Please don't complain about paying this fee, think about how much the taxi cost from your hotel to get there, and give them at least the same.please donate them as you much can.lovely visiting!!

I visited this Sea Turtle sanctuary many times during my Sri Lanka visit. The staff here are very passionate about taking care of both the beach and the sea turtles they care for. They work hard and are extremely knowledgeable about all the species of turtles they care for. They also care for the beach. It was fascinating to learn about these endangered sea turtles and to get to see them up close. I also got a chance to watch as they hatched, and helped to release them into the ocean at sunset. It was an amazing experience to watch the little hatchlings run towards the water! A highly recommended stop and an amazing experience!

Awesome place! We visited at 5pm one day in March and met a really professional and passionate staff member. This is a great hatchery, clearly an ethical and well run operation with the welfare and conservation of the turtles at the centre. We gave a donation, this was not pressurised like some we found as the focus of staff there is the turtles and not making money from tourists. We visited with my parents who were visiting from the UK and they had a simply phenomenal experience, spending time with the turtles in rehabilitation and to top it off we were able to release some baby turtles as it was considered to be safe to do so. This was a joy for us all, Thanks for such an amazing experience, simply memorable. This place really topped Ahungalla Turtle conservation project a few miles away who we found to be over-bearing to visitors and felt less ethical. Thank you so much for your kindness
